member.name: T:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.C1Magnify
member.summary: Represents the component which can be attached to any existing control, after long tap on the control, a magnifier will popup above the finger, and shows the info around the finger.

remarks.para: A form can attach two or more component, if has two or more fingers long tap on the attach control, only first magnifier popup.

example.para: The following code example shows how to use component.
You can copy the code to a exsit Windows Forms appliction. And set the form in the sample code as start form.
If you find a licenses error when run this code. Try to drag a component to a any Form from tool box can generate the licenses information to this project.

member.name: T:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.C1ZoomPanel
member.summary: Represents the component which can be enables you to group collections of controls and made these controls can be zoom by two finger touch.

remarks.para: When the loaded, will change all GcZoomPanel's children control to a inner panel. In run time, you should use GcZoomPanel.InnerControls property instead of GcZoomPanel.Controls
You can't use and together.
can't be a child of another .
The can't change the tooltip, contextMenu, common dialog's font and size.

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.C1ZoomPanel.ScrollLocation
member.summary: Gets or sets the scroll location of the panel.
member.value: A value that represents the scroll location of the panel in pixels.

remarks.para: The property represents the location of the visible portion of a the panel. Use this property to change the portion of the control that is displayed.

para.note: The and coordinate values retrieved are negative if the control has scrolled away from its starting position (0,0). When you set this property, you must always assign positive and values to set the scroll position relative to the starting position. For example, if you have a horizontal scroll bar and you set x and y to 200, you move the scroll 200 pixels to the right; if you then set x and y to 100, the scroll appears to jump the left by 100 pixels, because you are setting it 100 pixels away from the starting position. In the first case, returns {-200, 0}; in the second case, it returns {-100,0}.

remarks.para: If the set value bigger than scrollable maximum value, the will adjust the value to maximum value automatically. And also, if the set value smaller than scrollable minimum value, the will adjust the value to minimum value automatically.

example.para: The following code example shows how to use this property.
This code example is part of a larger example provided for the property.

member.name: T:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.C1ApplicationZoom
member.summary: Represents the component which can be attached to any existing form, and made all forms in current application can be zoom by two finger touch.

remarks.para: The will try to find all forms in current application, and then attach a component to the found forms. Before attach will initialize the 's setting by this own settings. And then raise and event. User can change the initial in this events' event handler and user can cancel attach in event by set 's property to .
If the form has attached a , the do not attach it again.
The can't make the tooltip, contextMenu, common dialog's has gesture zoom ability.

member.name: T:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.C1Zoom
member.summary: Represents the component which can be attached to any existing form, and made the form can be zoom by two finger touch.

remarks.para: When form load, GcZoom will change all form's children control to a inner panel. So after form loaded, you can't access children controls by Form.Controls property. You should use GcZoom.Controls property instead.
If the form contains a , can't attach to the form.
A form can't attach two or more GcZoom component.
The can't change the tooltip, contextMenu, common dialog's font and size.

example.para: The following code example shows how to configure component to get different zoom effect.
You can copy the code to a exsit Windows Forms appliction. And set the form in the sample code as start form.
If you find a licenses error when run this code. Try to drag a component to a any Form from tool box can generate the licenses information to this project.

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.C1Zoom.ScrollLocation
member.summary: Gets or sets the scroll location of the form.
member.value: A value that represents the scroll location of the form in pixels.

remarks.para: The property represents the location of the visible portion of a the form. Use this property to change the portion of the control that is displayed.

para.note: The and coordinate values retrieved are negative if the control has scrolled away from its starting position (0,0). When you set this property, you must always assign positive and values to set the scroll position relative to the starting position. For example, if you have a horizontal scroll bar and you set x and y to 200, you move the scroll 200 pixels to the right; if you then set x and y to 100, the scroll appears to jump the left by 100 pixels, because you are setting it 100 pixels away from the starting position. In the first case, returns {-200, 0}; in the second case, it returns {-100,0}.

remarks.para: If the set value bigger than scrollable maximum value, the will adjust the value to maximum value automatically. And also, if the set value smaller than scrollable minimum value, the will adjust the value to minimum value automatically.

example.para: The following code example shows how to use this property.
This code example is part of a larger example provided for the property.

member.name: T:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.ZoomPreviewMode
member.summary: Specifies how to display the form when gesture zooming.

member.name: F:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.ZoomPreviewMode.Bitmap
member.summary: Use bitmap preview when zooming.

remarks.para: Benefit: User can get immediately result when zooming. High performance.
Weakness: The bitmap come from 's method, it has some limitation. For example, do not support ActiveX control.
Suits to: Most of case.

member.name: F:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.ZoomPreviewMode.NoPreview
member.summary: Do not preview when zooming.

remarks.para: Benefit: User can get immediately result when zooming. Do not have any preview limitation.
Weakness: Performance is not good.
Suits to: Very simple form with a few children controls.

member.name: F:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.ZoomPreviewMode.AlternativeContent
member.summary: Use the alternative content preview when zooming.

remarks.para: Benefit: Do not have any preview limitation. Performance is very good.
Weakness: User can't get immediately result when zooming.
Suits to: Very heavy or complex form.

list.item: User actions that change the relationship of the display area, such as changing resolution or monitor settings
Input interactions such as a stylus touching the same surface as a previous touch action

member.name: T:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties
member.summary: Provides extended properties for a object.

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.ContactRect
member.summary: Gets the bounding rectangle of the contact area (typically from touch input).
member.value: The bounding rectangle of the contact area, using client window coordinates in device-independent pixels (DIPs).

remarks.para: contains the bounding rectangle of the contact area as interpreted by the system. Under some circumstances, such as input prediction, this data can be modified by the system to compensate for hardware latency or message latency due to inherent delays in sensing and processing the pointer location on the digitizer.
See for more information on raw input data.

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.ContactRectRaw
member.summary: Gets the bounding rectangle of the raw input (typically from touch input).
member.value: The bounding rectangle of the raw input, in device-independent pixels (DIPs)

remarks.para: contains the bounding rectangle of the raw input as reported by the input device. Under some circumstances, such as input prediction, this data can be modified by the system to compensate for hardware latency or message latency due to inherent delays in sensing and processing the pointer location on the digitizer.
See for more information on handling modified input data.

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.IsBarrelButtonPressed
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the barrel button of the pen/stylus device is pressed.
member.value: if the barrel button is pressed; otherwise, .

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.IsCanceled
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the input was canceled by the pointer device.
member.value: if the input was canceled; otherwise, .

remarks.para: Pointer input can be canceled for various reasons, including:

list.item: Input arbitration (such as pen/stylus proximity overriding touch input)

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.IsEraser
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the input is from a digitizer eraser.
member.value: if the input is from a digitizer eraser; otherwise, .

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.IsInRange
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the physical entity (finger or pen) is in range of the digitizer.
member.value: if in range; otherwise, .

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.IsInverted
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the digitizer pen is inverted.
member.value: if inverted; otherwise, .

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.IsPrimary
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the input is from the primary pointer when multiple pointers are registered.
member.value: if the input is from the pointer designated as primary; otherwise, .
member.remarks: A primary pointer can perform actions that are not available to other pointers. For example, the primary pointer can send a WM_POINTERACTIVATE message when it makes contact with a window.

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.Orientation
member.summary: Gets the counter-clockwise angle of rotation around the major axis of the pointer device (the z-axis, perpendicular to the surface of the digitizer). A value of 0.0 degrees indicates the device is oriented towards the top of the digitizer.
member.value: A value between 0.0 and 359.0 in degrees of rotation. The default value is 0.0.
member.remarks: Orientation is also referred to as azimuth.

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.Pressure
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates the force that the pointer device (typically a pen/stylus) exerts on the surface of the digitizer.
member.value: A value from 0 to 1.0. The default value is 0.5.

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.TouchConfidence
member.summary: Gets a value that indicates whether the pointer device rejected the touch contact.
member.value: if the touch contact was accepted; otherwise, .

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.Twist
member.summary: Gets the clockwise rotation in degrees of a pen device around its own major axis (such as when the user spins the pen in their fingers).
member.value: A value between 0.0 and 359.0 in degrees of rotation. The default value is 0.0.

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.XTilt
member.summary: Gets the plane angle between the Y-Z plane and the plane that contains the Y axis and the axis of the input device (typically a pen/stylus).
member.value: The value is 0.0 when the finger or pen is perpendicular to the digitizer surface, between 0.0 and 179.0 when tilted to the right of perpendicular, and between 0.0 and -179.0 when tilted to the left of perpendicular. The default value is 0.0.

member.name: P:C1.Win.TouchToolKit.PointerPointProperties.YTilt
member.summary: Gets the plane angle between the X-Z plane and the plane that contains the X axis and the axis of the input device (typically a pen/stylus).
member.value: The value is 0.0 when the finger or pen is perpendicular to the digitizer surface, between 0.0 and -179.0 when tilted towards the user, and between 0.0 and 179.0 when tilted away from the user. The default value is 0.0.
